Number of missingness

n_missing.Rd

This function checks number of missingness in a vector, or a data.frame or data table. It returns the results in exact number (percentage) or returns the index of missingness

Usage

n_missing(x, na_strings = c(""), index = FALSE)

mi2(x, na_strings = c(""), index = FALSE)

Arguments

x

(vector or data.frame or data.table) the object to be checked

na_strings

(character) a character vector of strings which are to be interpreted as NA values. The default for n_missing is "", which will treat empty strings as NA.

index

(logical) If true the function returns the index of the missing values instead of the number (percentage). For vector input, a logical vector of same length will be returned. For data.frame or data.table input, the function returns a vector with length equal to the number of rows of input table and any missingness in the row will result in a returned value of TRUE for the row.

Value

(character or logical) For vector input, a character vector the same length of x where each value represents whether that particular element is missing. For data.frame or data.table input, a logical vector of which the length is the number of rows of input table and each value represents whether any element of the row is missing.

Examples

df <- data.frame(
  x = c(1, 2, NA, 4, 5),
  y = as.POSIXct(c("2023-12-01 15:00", "2021-07-09 19:30", "2020-01-02 09:00",
                   "1998-08-23 15:23", NA)),
  z = c("NA", NA, "a", " ", ""),
  v = as.Date(c("2023-10-23", "2012-06-30", NA, "2023-08-12", "2009-01-01"))
)
n_missing(df)
#>           x           y           z           v 
#> "1 (20.0%)" "1 (20.0%)" "2 (40.0%)" "1 (20.0%)" 
n_missing(df$z)
#> [1] "2 (40.0%)"
n_missing(df, na_strings = c("", "NA", " "))
#>           x           y           z           v 
#> "1 (20.0%)" "1 (20.0%)" "4 (80.0%)" "1 (20.0%)" 
n_missing(df$z, index = TRUE)
#> [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE
n_missing(df, na_strings = c("", "NA", " "), index = TRUE)
#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE
